instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> RAM beeps on boot
threads.message:
Took a while but got my first retina board with a RAM issue. A visual inspection showed L7710 with half of the top missing (can see inside the coil) and a few solder balls on/stuck to <CAPACITOR>C7714</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7715</CAPACITOR>. No other visual cues and as far as I know, these backlight parts have nothing to do with the RAM. 

Is there a way to find out which RAM chip is the issue, if at all? Can other issues cause the RAM beeps on retina boards?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> RAM beeps on boot
threads.message:
DDR power rails present? Case broken on a coil is nothing, BUT, it could have broke if it fell

Hmm... What else could have gotten cracked if it fell?

Ram solder balls... 

DO NOT reflow them until you make sure you have all your DDR rails.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> RAM beeps on boot
threads.message: I bet it took an impact and ripped traces under RAM/CPU. If 1.35V is present to the RAM this board can go in the trash pile.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> RAM beeps on boot
threads.message: Not seeing them on the schematic. Assuming I should just go after everything "DDRREG"?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> RAM beeps on boot
threads.message: 1.35V is present. Guess this can be marked as solved. Thanks fellas :)
